24 Ex. <s>32<\s> On viewing a set of Newtonian rings as described 
in Experiment 4<s>12<\s> through one of the double slips, while 
in the position fig. 11<s>13<\s> & the apparatus forming the rings 
was on the table; a set of narrow binary rings appeared 
concentric to the primaries, & near to the edge of the 
lenses: & on lowering the double slip to the second po-
sition Fig 13<s>15<\s> another set of binary rings appeared in 
the reflected Image of the double slip, also concentric 
to the primaries, but consisting of broader rings, tho 
less in diameter than those of the first set; and all 
these three sets <s>were<s\> were seen distinctly, at one & the same 
time. 
The two sets of binary rings, seen in this experiment 
correspond to the two irregular spectra in experiment 20<s>28<\s>; 
& since the. rings must have been formed between the lenses 
on the table (because no <u>Rings<\u> are ever formed unless 
between surfaces one of which at least is spherical) this 
affords a corroborating proof that the irregular spectra 
seen in Experiment 20<s>28<\s>, altho apparently formed in the 
Air were really formed between the two slips of glass 
lying on the table. 
The above results differ so widely from any that have 
hitherto been published; that it is allowable to doubt whether 
they can be accounted for on the common & received 
principles of physical optics. +
